title: 104_hr1777
content: The Act may be cited as the "Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995". Amendments are also included in the Act. The "Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995" amends the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include definitions related to air traffic controllers. The "Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995" updates the United States Code to define 'air traffic controller' as a civilian employee in a supervisory or technical position within the Department of Transportation or Defense. The "Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995" updates the United States Code to define 'air traffic controller' as a civilian employee in a supervisory or technical position within the Department of Transportation or Defense. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE; OTHER PROVISIONS. The "Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995" states that the Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment. Employee contributions for service as a controller will be treated as if the amendments were in effect at the time of service. The "Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995" requires employee contributions for service as a controller to be treated as if the amendments were in effect at the time of service, with a deposit requirement into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The "Air Traffic Supervisor Retirement Reform Act of 1995" requires employee contributions for service as a controller to be treated as if the amendments were in effect at the time of service, with a deposit requirement into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The deductions or deposits made under section 8334 or 8422 of title 5, United States Code, must exceed the amount rendered for such service. This provision does not apply to individuals not serving as a controller at the time of application. The Office will accept the certification of the Secretary of Transportation or Defense regarding an individual's service and compensation for applications under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5, United States Code. The agency must pay into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund the full deposit required for an individual within 90 days, along with interest. The Office will prescribe regulations for the Disability Fund, including application and deposit procedures, and interest computation. The regulations for the Disability Fund will include interest computation and application procedures. Section 8335(a) or 8425(a) of title 5, United States Code, does not mandate the separation of a controller appointed before the effective date of this Act.
